content: - Settlement of Nile Valley begins.

- Kingdoms of Upper and Lower Egypt unite. Successive dynasties witness flourishing trade, prosperity and the development of great cultural traditions. Writing, including hieroglyphics, is used as an instrument of state. Construction of the pyramids - around 2,500 BC - is a formidable engineering achievement.
- Assyrians from Mesopotamia conquer and rule Egypt.
- Persian conquest.
- Alexander the Great, of ancient Macedonia, conquers Egypt, founds Alexandria. A Macedonian dynasty rules until 31 BC.
- Egypt comes under Roman rule; Queen Cleopatra commits suicide after Octavian's army defeats her forces.
- Christianity comes to Egypt, and by 4th century has largely displaced Egyptian religion.
- Arab conquest of Egypt.
- Cairo established as capital.
- Mameluke (slave soldier) rule, characterised by great prosperity and well-ordered civic institutions.
- Egypt absorbed into the Turkish Ottoman empire.
- Napoleon Bonaparte's forces invade but are repelled by the British and the Turks in 1801.
- Ottoman Albanian commander Muhammad Ali establishes dynasty that goes on to reign until 1953, although nominally part of the Ottoman Empire.
- Suez Canal built, but it and other infrastructure projects near-bankrupt Egypt and lead to gradual British takeover.
- British troops defeat Egyptian army and take control of country.
- Egypt formally becomes a British protectorate.
- Fuad I becomes king and Egypt gains independence, although British influence remains significant until 1950s.
- Muslim Brotherhood founded by Hassan al-Banna, who is killed in 1949. Campaigns to reorient Egypt and whole Muslim Middle East away from Western influence.
- Egypt, Iraq, Jordan and Syria attack the new state of Israel. Egyptian army's poor performance increases unpopularity of King Farouk.
- Committee of the Free Officers' Movement formed to overthrow corrupt monarchy.
January - At least 20 people are killed in anti-British riots in Cairo.
July - Coup by the Free Officers' Movement. Farouk abdicates in favour of his infant son Ahmed Fuad II.
June - Coup leader Muhammad Najib becomes president as Egypt is declared a republic.
- Fellow coup leader Gamal Abdel Nasser becomes prime minister and in 1956 president, ruling unchallenged until his death in 1970.
- Evacuation Treaty signed. British forces, who began a gradual withdrawal under 1936 treaty, finally leave Egypt.
- Prime Minister Nasser reorients Egypt away from West towards neutrality, buys arms from Communist Czechoslovakia to re-equip arm.
January - Egypt and Britain relinquish control over Sudan, established at end of 19th century.
July - President Nasser nationalises the Suez Canal to fund the Aswan High Dam, after Britain and US withdraw financing.
October-November - Invasion of Egypt by Britain, France and Israel over nationalisation of Suez Canal fails through US opposition, greatly enhancing President Nasser's standing at home and abroad.

- President Nasser steps up campaign to promote pan-Arab unity, most visible signs of which is brief United Arab Republic unitary state including Syria (1958-61). He also supports friendly elements in Lebanese and North Yemen conflicts, to little avail.

- President Nasser adopts socialist policies, including nationalisation of industry and an ambitious welfare programme, combined with repression of Muslim Brotherhood and leftist opponents, in an unsuccessful attempt to boost the economy and the popularity of his government.
May - Egypt expels UN buffer forces from Sinai and closes the Straits of Tiran to Israeli ships, then sign defence pact with Jordan. Israel interprets this as preparation for war.
June - Israeli pre-emptive attack defeats Egypt, Jordan and Syria, leaving it in control of Sinai up to the Suez Canal and Egyptian-occupied Gaza.
Emergency Law largely suspends civil rights. Remains in force with brief break in early 1980s until 2012.
September - Nasser dies, having never recovered his leading role among Arab states after the 1967 defeat, and is succeeded by Vice-President Anwar al-Sadat.
- The Aswan High Dam is completed, with Soviet funding, and has a huge impact on irrigation, agriculture and industry in Egypt.
- President Sadat expels Soviet advisers and reorients Egypt towards the West, while launching an ultimately unsuccessful attempt to open the economy to market forces and foreign investment.
October - Egypt and Syria go to war with Israel to reclaim land lost in 1967. Egypt begins negotiations for the return of Sinai after the war.
June - The Suez Canal is re-opened for first time since 1967 war.
January - "Bread riots" in major cities against end to subsidies on basic foodstuffs under agreement with World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

October - President Sadat visits Israel, beginning process that leads to 1979 peace treaty, return of occupied Sinai Peninsula, and Egypt's suspension from Arab League until 1989. Egypt becomes major beneficiary of US financial aid.
October - President Sadat assassinated by Islamist extremists month after clampdown on private press and opposition groups in wake of anti-government riots. Succeeded by Vice-President Hosni Mubarak.
President Mubarak reimposes state of emergency, restricting political activity, freedom of expression and assembly.
- Amy deployed in Cairo to crush mutiny by Central Security paramilitary police.

- Egypt joins allied coalition to expel Iraqi troops from Kuwait, and benefited from major multilateral loans and debt relief in return, allowing government to launch another attempt at liberalising economy.
- Gama'a al-Islamiyya Islamic Group begins five-year campaign of attacks on government and tourist targets, culminating in killing of 62 people at Luxor historic site in 1997.
May - Referendum backs constitutional amendment allowing multiple candidates at presidential elections, after months of opposition protests.
July - Scores of people are killed in bomb attacks in the Red Sea resort of Sharm al-Sheikh as Islamists resume terror attacks.
December - Parliamentary polls end with clashes between police and supporters of the opposition Muslim Brotherhood, who win record 20% of seats by standing as independents.
April - Bomb attacks in the Red Sea resort of Dahab kill more than 20 people.
November - Egypt is one of at least six Arab countries developing domestic nuclear programmes to diversify energy sources, the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) reports.
November - Parliamentary polls, followed by protests against alleged vote rigging. Muslim Brotherhood fails to win a single seat, though it held a fifth of the places in the last parliament.
January - Anti-government demonstrations, apparently encouraged by Tunisian street protests which prompted sudden departure of President Ben Ali.
February - President Mubarak steps down and hands power to an army council. Goes on trial in August, charged with ordering the killing of demonstrators.
April-August - Protests continue in Cairo's Tahrir Square over slow pace of political change. Islamist groups come to the fore. Army finally disperses protesters in August.
November - Violence in Cairo's Tahrir Square as security forces clash with protesters accusing the military of trying to keep their grip on power.
January - Islamist parties emerge as victors of drawn-out parliamentary elections.
May - Military leaders announce the end of the state of emergency in place since Anwar al-Sadat's assassination in 1981.
June - Muslim Brotherhood candidate Mohammed Morsi narrowly wins presidential election.
August - Islamist fighters attack an army outpost in Sinai, killing 16 soldiers, and mount a brief incursion into Israel, beginning new insurgency.
December - Islamist-dominated constituent assembly approves draft constitution that boosts the role of Islam and restricts freedom of speech and assembly.
January - More than 50 people are killed during days of violent street protests. Army chief Abdul Fattah al-Sisi warns that political strife is pushing the state to the brink of collapse.
July - Army overthrows President Morsi amid mass demonstrations calling on him to quit.  Hundreds are killed as security forces storm pro-Morsi protest camps in Cairo the following month.
December - Government declares Muslim Brotherhood a terrorist group after a bomb blast in Mansoura kills 12.
January - New constitution bans parties based on religion.
May - Former army chief Abdul Fattah al-Sisi wins presidential election.
November - Sinai-based armed group Ansar Beit al-Maqdis pledges allegiance to extreme Islamic State movement, which controls parts of Syria and Iraq. Renames itself Sinai Province.
May -  Ousted President Morsi sentenced to death over 2011 mass breakout of Muslim Brotherhood prisoners, along with more than 100 others.
June - Prosecutor-General Hisham Barakat and three members of the public killed in suspected Islamist car bombing in Cairo.
July - Islamic State launches wave of attacks in North Sinai and on Coptic churches nationwide.
October - Islamic State claims responsibility for destruction of Russian airliner in Sinai, in which all crew and 224 tourist passengers were killed.
January - Islamic State carries out attack at Giza tourist site and is suspected of attack on tourists in Hurghada.
November - IMF approves a three-year $12bn loan to Egypt designed to help the country out of its deep economic crisis.
Egyptian security forces have struggled to stop attacks by jihadists in North Sinai
April - State of emergency declared after suicide bombers kill dozens at two churches where worshippers celebrated Palm Sunday.
June - Egypt joins Saudi-led campaign to isolate Qatar, accusing it of promoting terrorism.
November - Jihadists attack mosque in Bir al-Abed village in North Sinai, killing 305.
March - President Sisi wins a second term in elections against a sole minor opposition candidate. More serious challengers either withdrew or were arrested.
October - Seventeen people are sentenced to death over the 2016-17 wave of Islamic State group attacks on churches, and a further 19 receive life sentences.
